However, it is a little different than some of the older languages, and it can be tough to learn Python on your own. Learning Python is easy and fast when you take advantage of Codementor Python and training experts.

https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Program.title: Practical Programming: An introduction to computer science using Python 3 2nd Edition
https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Program.descriptionText: Teaches the fundamentals of programming using Python 3. An excellent resource with a lot of practice exercises and also delves deep into python.

https://talkpython.fm/.title: Talk Python Podcast
https://talkpython.fm/.descriptionText: Explores the opportunities, industries and possibilities of Python

https://learnpythonthehardway.org/book/.title: Learn Python The Hard Way
https://learnpythonthehardway.org/book/.descriptionText: Learn Python the Hard Way is a great introduction to Python for the beginner.

https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm-edu/.title: (free) Intellj-based Python IDE with integrated adaptive Python course
https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm-edu/.descriptionText: Intellj is an extremely powerful IDE that is widely used in production. Learning language and tools at the same time can be powerful, especially considering that the course adapts to the learner (e.g. tasks change as a function of learners skill)

https://www.codeschool.com/.title: codeschool - Python is one of the languages you can learn there.
https://www.codeschool.com/.descriptionText: Great resource to get you started with programming - a lot of free info and courses as well.

http://rosalind.info.title: Rosalind - Tool to learn coding through problem solving. Problems related to bioinformatics.

https://www.hackerrank.com/.title: Hacker Rank - problems to solve within online interpreter
https://www.hackerrank.com/.descriptionText: problems to solve within online interpreter; has section devoted to Python as well as may separate algorithms section and many others (math, AI, data structions, more) in which you can choose to use Python2/3 to solve

https://automatetheboringstuff.com/.title: Automate the Boring Stuff with Python
https://automatetheboringstuff.com/.descriptionText: Free eBook that helps complete beginners with Python.

http://devdocs.io/.title: devdocs.io unified documentation for python and additional libraries (numpy etc)
http://devdocs.io/.descriptionText: visually appealing interface to the python documentation, available offline

http://greenteapress.com/wp/think-python.title: Think Python 2e
http://greenteapress.com/wp/think-python.descriptionText: Think Python is an introduction to Python programming for beginners. It starts with basic concepts of programming, and is carefully designed to define all terms when they are first used and to develop each new concept in a logical progression. Larger pieces, like recursion and object-oriented programming are divided into a sequence of smaller steps and introduced over the course of several chapters.

http://reddit.com/r/learnpython.title: Reddit's Learn Python sub
http://reddit.com/r/learnpython.descriptionText: If you're stuck toss up the question and lots of knowledgeable people will jump in and help you out.

https://www.reddit.com/r/learnpython.descriptionText: Feel free to ask any python related questions.
